title: RS22060
content: The Aquatic Resources Trust Fund was established in 1984 by the Wallop-Breaux Amendment to the Federal Aid in Sport Fish Restoration program. It consists of the Sport Fish Restoration Account and the Boat Safety Account, which was terminated in 2005. The fund was renamed the Sport Fish Restoration and Boating Trust Fund and receives income from five sources. The Trust Fund receives income from five sources, including motorboat fuel taxes, small engine fuel taxes, and manufacturers' excise tax on sport fishing equipment. Annual income from these sources exceeds $350 million, $100 million, and is projected to be about $112 million for FY2012, respectively. The excise tax on sport fishing equipment is a permanent annual appropriation to the Sport Fish Restoration and Boating Trust Fund. Income from this source has been around $100 million annually, with a projected income of about $103 million for FY2012. Additionally, the account receives annual receipts from import duties on fishing tackle and yachts, with income from this source projected to be about $38 million for FY2012. The account also receives interest on funds invested prior to disbursal. The account receives interest on funds invested prior to disbursal, with annual income fluctuating based on interest rates. Approximately $86 million is estimated for FY2012. Income received in one fiscal year is allocated to programs in the following year, with $626 million available for distribution in FY2012. Eight programs are funded, including the Coastal Wetlands Planning, Protection, and Restoration Act. Title X of P.L. 109-59 increased allocation to 18.5% through June 30, 2012. From the Sport Fish Restoration and Boating Trust Fund, $110.4 million is estimated for FY2012. 15% goes to National Coastal Wetlands Conservation Grants Program, 70% to Corps of Engineers Louisiana Coastal Wetlands Restoration Program, and 15% to North American Wetlands Conservation Fund. Appropriations are authorized through FY2019. The U.S. Coast Guard's Office of Boating Safety administers a boating safety program funded by 18.5% of annual receipts from the Sport Fish Restoration and Boating Trust Fund. The program receives about $110.4 million for FY2012 and provides grants to states and nonprofit organizations for recreational boating safety. The Clean Vessel Act of 1992 authorizes a grant program for states to construct pump-out and dump stations. The Clean Vessel Act of 1992 authorizes a grant program for states to construct pump-out and dump stations for recreational boaters. The program annually receives 2% of the annual receipts to the Sport Fish Restoration and Boating Trust Fund, totaling over $10 million in state grants. Another program, the Boating Infrastructure Grant Program, provides matching funds to states for docking facilities for transient recreational boats 26 feet or more in length. The current authorization for the allocation of state grants through the Sport Fish Restoration and Boating Trust Fund extends until June 30, 2012. The Recreational Boating and Fishing Foundation, established in 1998, aims to increase participation in recreational boating and fishing and promote aquatic stewardship. Annual grants are provided to improve communication with anglers, boaters, and the public. The Wildlife and Sport Fish Restoration Program Improvement Act of 2000 authorized a Multi-State Conservation Grant Program with annual funding available. The Secretary of the Interior receives up to $3 million annually from the Sport Fish Restoration and Boating Trust Fund. Additional funds are allocated to Interstate Fishery Commissions and the Sport Fishing and Boating Partnership Council. In FY2012, a total of $1.2 million will be available for these programs. The Sport Fish Restoration Program receives funding from the Sport Fish Restoration and Boating Trust Fund to grant state agencies funding based on a formula. States receive funding based on the number of licensed anglers and land/water area. Around $400 million is allocated to states annually through this program. Projects funded by the Sport Fish Restoration Program can include land acquisition, development, research, operations, maintenance, and sport fish population management. Prohibited activities are law enforcement and public relations. States must certify licensed anglers, agree not to misuse funds, and provide a 75% match for most projects. Annual administrative expenses are around $10 million, with a maximum limitation specified. Funding for administrative expenses for the Boating Safety Program is specified in 16 U.S.C. 777c(b) and estimated to be about $15 million in FY2012. Prior to P.L. 109-59, no funds were appropriated from the Boat Safety Account for state recreational boating safety grants. The Boat Safety Account was terminated according to P.L. 109-59, and program expenditures were supported by the spend-down of assets. Proposals for reauthorizing federal surface transportation programs may include an increase in the federal fuel tax to fund highway infrastructure programs. The 112th Congress is considering increasing the federal fuel tax to benefit the Sport Fish Restoration and Boating Trust Fund by over $350 million annually. Questions arise on how to modify programs supported by the fund if the tax increase is enacted. Fund allocations are set to expire on June 30, 2012, as comprehensive transportation legislation has not been passed yet. Multiple bills aim to extend fund authorizations through FY2013. The 112th Congress is considering extending fund authorizations through FY2017 with various bills introduced and passed in both the Senate and House committees. On April 24, 2012, the Senate passed H.R. 4348 after amending it with the language of the Senate-passed S. 1813. The 112th Congress is considering extending fund authorizations through FY2017 with various bills introduced and passed in both the Senate and House committees. The Senate passed H.R. 4348 after amending it with the language of S. 1813, proposing to allocate a portion of oil and gas revenues in Alaska for federal sport fish restoration grants.
